instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont turn on
threads.message:
I have this device here, no green/orange light, dont turn on.

found short <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> Pin 1 to ground and high resistant <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR>

after replacing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> there was no short anymore.

So i replaced the <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> after that all was ok but i found there goes 6A in to the machine.

So I replaced both <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/2 again. After that the current in to the machine didnt rise over 3.6A

So I thought everything fine, gave it back the client. machine came in today with the same problem.


So i replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/2, after that again no short but on mac safe no green/orange light, machine working good.

So I still replaced the DC-in conector. After that I got green/orange light. current in to the machine again until 3.6A

So I still have any idea what can be here the problem. I think, if I will give it back to the client it will break again.

Is it possible that the dc-in still was broken and that was the main reason?

is 20V on the laboratory-unit correct for <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont turn on
threads.message:
Don't you have original Magsafe 2 85W charger?
Normal voltage is 18V aprox.
Probably the client has fake charger...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont turn on
threads.message:
is it possible that the dc-in  was the problem ?

yes, i have a original charger, will try that, had only the lab-unit tryed

threads.message:
I tryed with my original  charger , no problems.
my client told me he have a good original one too, here a pic.

[ATTACH type="full"]59261[/ATTACH]


can u imagine that it could be possible a bad dc in board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont turn on
threads.message:
is it possible that there could be from the beginning the main problem a bad dc-in board?
can to much current caused by a bad dc-in board damage the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/2 ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont turn on
threads.message: DCIN board shouldn't generate such damage.

is there any way to test it ?
